metadata./Title: Superficial acral fibromyxoma on the palm: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Superficial acral fibromyxoma is a noncancerous, benign tumor of soft tissue with an unidentified origin. Occurrences of abnormalities on the palm are less frequently documented.
Case report presentation A 47-year-old East Asian woman presented with a palm tumor on her left knuckle 
that had been present for 4 months. Four months prior to treatment, a reddish nodule appeared at the site due 
to continuous friction, but the patient did not pay attention to it. Upon physical examination, a pale-reddish nodule 
measuring approximately 0.8 × 0.8 cm was observed on the flexion side of the fourth metacarpophalangeal joint 
of the left hand. The nodule was nearly round, exhibited distinct margins, featured slight surface keratosis, and displayed a collar-like alteration at its periphery. The stroma showed significant fibrous proliferation and a myxoid matrix. 
The cellular composition consisted primarily of spindle-shaped fibroblasts, which were locally arranged in bundles 
within the stroma. Sparse slender blood vessels were distributed along with observed red blood cell extravasation. 
Immunohistochemistry of the tumor showed CD34 (+), CD99 (−), desmin (−), epithelial membrane antigen (−). Extensive resection of the mass was performed.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion A rounded mass on the palm of the hand may be superficial acral fibromyxoma. The optimal approach 
for treating superficial acral fibromyxoma involves complete surgical removal of the mass followed by postoperative 
monitoring.

sections.Introduction:
Introduction
Superficial acral fibromyxoma (SAF) is a noncancerous 
soft-tissue tumor observed primarily in middle-aged 
adults, with a higher occurrence among males [1–3]. By 
contrast, only a few isolated cases have been reported 
in East Asian countries [3]. Painless and gradual growth 
is usually seen in the extremities of the hands and toes, 
the majority growing near the nail [1, 3, 4]. Malignant 
transformation has never been reported in this tumor. 
SAF has also been reported to grow on the surface 
of plantar and nail matrix [5, 6]. From a pathological perspective, the anomaly comprises a combination of 
astrocytes and spindle cells within a fibrous myxoid 
matrix. Immunohistochemical manifestations are 
varied. Most cases report that the tumor is usually 
immunopositive for CD34 and CD99 [7, 8]. To the best 
of our knowledge, the literature on superficial acral 
fibromyxoma of the palm is very limited.
Case report presentation
A 47-year-old East Asian woman presented with a palm 
tumor on her left knuckle that had been present for 
4  months. Four months prior to treatment, a reddish 
nodule appeared at the site due to continuous friction, 
but the patient did not pay attention to it. Upon physical 
examination, a pale-reddish nodule measuring approxi mately 0.8 × 0.8  cm was observed on the flexion side of Open Access

The nodule was nearly round, exhibited distinct margins, 
featured slight surface keratosis, and displayed a collarlike alteration at its periphery. No signs of redness, ero sion, or exudation were noted (Fig. 1).
The tumor was located in the dermis, without a clear 
capsule. The stroma showed significant fibrous prolifera tion and a myxoid matrix (Fig. 2).
The cellular composition consisted primarily of spin dle-shaped fibroblasts, which were locally arranged in 
bundles within the stroma. The cells exhibited no evident 
atypia, and sparse slender blood vessels were distributed 
along with observed red blood cell extravasation (Fig. 3).
The immunohistochemistry of the tumor showed CD34 
positivity and negativity for CD99, desmin, and epithelial 
membrane antigen (EMA) (Fig.  4). Extensive resection 
of the mass was performed. Lesion enlargement, local 
recurrence, or distant metastases were not detected dur ing the follow-up period.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
SAF was first reported by Fetch in 2001 [9]. It is 
one of the solitary tissue masses that involve peri- 
and subungual acral regions [1]. The etiology and 
predisposing factors for SAF are unclear. The tumor 
is often presented as dome-shaped or verrucous with 
an average diameter of 0.6–5  cm [10]. The case we 
are reporting involves the dermis, and as Hollmann 
discovered, most lesions infiltrate the dermis collagen 
[1]. In terms of cytomorphology, moderately cellularproliferating spindle-shaped fibroblasts and stellate 
cells were distributed in stellate and fascicular patterns 
and embedded in a myxoid and/or collagenous 
matrix. The matrix contained mildly and moderately 
pronounced blood vessels [1]. Most cases of SAF show immunoreactivity for CD34 and CD99 and, less 
frequently, for EMA [11]. Almost all tumors were 
negative with S100 [11]. As for this case, tumor cells were 
positive only for CD34. One study showed that nestin is 
more sensitive than CD34 as an immunohistochemical 
marker in terms of identifying SAF [11]. Immunological 
markers indicate that the pathogenesis of SAF may be 
related to mesenchymal stem cells. CD34 positivity is 
not sufficient for the diagnosis of SAF, nor is it a unique 
feature. It requires a combination of clinical, histologic, 
and immunohistochemical features to make a diagnosis.
Therefore, accurate diagnosis is essential for treatment 
planning and prevention of overtreatment.
In one study, X-ray analysis showed that 36% of SAF 
affects bone tissue with a well-defined presentation [1]. 
Four of the 37 cases reported by Fetsch et  al. showed 
depression or scalloping of the underlying bone [9]. 
Although the X-ray findings of SAF are nonspecific, 
routine X-ray examination can help rule out some 
malignancies.
Ultrasound can help determine the size of the lesion 
and the scope of excision, especially in distinguishing

literature on this subject is limited [12].
It should be differentiated from other myxoid tumors, 
including digital myxoma, ossifying fibromyxoid tumor, 
low-grade myxofibrosarcoma, myxoid eurothekeoma, 
myxoid nodular fasciitis, myxoid neurofibroma, 
melanoma squamous cell carcinoma, and low-grade 
chondrosarcoma.
Nonetheless, it has been previously reported that this 
mass can lead to detachment of the underlying bone 
and impede the range of motion of the smaller joints 
[13]. Surgical excision is the most effective treatment 
for these benign tumors [4]. Holman et al. reported that 
ten patients relapsed after a mean interval of 27 months 
[1]. The average interval was 27  months [8]. One study 
showed a recurrence rate of 13% at a follow-up of more 
than 2 years [3].
If recurrence occurs, prompt excision is recommended. 
Complete excision and close follow-up are advised.
Conclusion
SAF is a nonmalignant, slow-developing soft-tissue 
tumor that usually appears in the limbs and has distinct 
clinical and pathological characteristic findings. Our case 
displayed a rare case of palm involvement. Prompt and 
precise diagnosis, followed by a thorough excision, is 
essential.
